scenes.location: OF BASEMENT ENTRANCE OF APT. HO
characters: CAMERA PULLS BACK RAPIDLY NOW TO REVEAL
NINTH FLOOR OF THE APARTMENT HOUSE -
MACHINE SHOP AND STOREROOM IN BASEMEN
DESK OF JULIA WOLFE'S APARTMENT HOUSE.
AS CAMERA PULLS BACK RAPIDLY TO REVEAL
STAIRWAY FROM BASEMENT TO FIRST FLOOR -
A RADIO IN A NEW YORK APARTMENT
CAMERA PULLS BACK TO REVEAL THE BAR OF A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shadow, grotesquely thin, is cast by one  strong light which reflects itself against a  white cement wall.  When we first see the shad- ow, it is standing upright, examining some- thing which it holds in its hands.  Now the  shadow bends down and as it does so, CAMERA  PULLS BACK TO REVEAL CLYDE WYNANT in his work- shop.  He is a tall, thin man of about fifty- five, with white hair.  He has a fine, sensi- tive face.  He is a very successful inventor.   A man who is capable of sudden fits of anger  which he forgets almost immediately, but which  are quite terrifying while they last.  Just now  he is utterly absorbed in what he is doing --  working on a delicately-wired part which has to  do with a new form of combustion engine that he  has invented.  (Through the entire scene, from  the first shadow effect, we hear the engine in  operation as he is working over it.)  Wynant is  dressed in overalls, and possibly a long shade  over his eyes.  The shop itself is in the base- ment of a small warehouse building, in the thir- ties between First Avenue and the East River,  in New York.  It is a long and narrow machine  shop, full of interest and character in its  mechanical layout.  Miniatures of engine-models  of various kinds -- vats of molten lead -- car- bon racks -- welding instruments -- delicate  light bulbs, and such other apparatus as com- poses a combination shop and laboratory of this  machine type.  WE HOLD A MOMENT on Wynant in the midst of an experiment over the combustion engine. Then from the background a workman  named Tom, also dressed in overalls, a man of  about thirty-five, comes in from an adjoining  shop.  He comes toward Wynant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your daughter's here, Mr. Wynant. (then, as Wynant doesn't seem to  hear him, he speaks louder)  Mr. Wynant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wynant, startled out of his absorption, drops a  delicate piece of metal (or whatever fragile  wiring or part he would be holding), and turns  furiously on Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you any more sense than to shout at me  like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: its edges are spoiled) Two weeks work gone for nothing.   Tom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to tell you... Wynant (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what you wanted to tell me.  You're  through!  Get your things and get out! The workman shrugs his shoulders and starts  away.  WE PAN Wynant to a bench on which there  are several acetylene torches.  He is examining  the part as he goes, muttering and growling to  himself. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good thing I'm going away -- no peace -- no  quiet.  Everybody interrupting me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOROTHY WYNANT comes to the door and looks in.   Tom is seen taking off his overalls, prepara- tory to leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom looks up as she speaks to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Miss Wynant.  He didn't give me a chance. Dorothy comes in, followed by ANDREW READE.  She  is a young girl of about twenty-one, spirited  and high-tempered like her father.  She has great  natural beauty and distinction ...  the crisp pro- duct of a strict finishing school.  She is  dressed in smart, simple street dress, with a  fur coat over it. Andrew Reade is a good-looking boy fresh from  college.  He gives an impression of reliability  and common sense.  CAMERA PANS WITH THEM as they  go toward the workbench and Wynant. Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! Wynant straightens up, and as he looks and sees  that it is his daughter, his whole expression  changes.  He forgets his anger.  he is delighted  to see her. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't they tell me you were here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to interrupt your work, but this is impor- tant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wynant looks over at Andrew standing behind  Dorothy.  Andrew smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wynant (to Dorothy - as he turns off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the combustion engine) Another young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy (as if she were speaking to a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: child who didn't remember his lessons)  It's been the same one for three months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me. (he shakes Andrew's hand) How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a good look at him, Dad. (Wynant looks at Andrew and smiles)  Now please try to remember him...  'cause he's going to  be your son-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wynant's look changes to one of serious interest. Wynant (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy has spoken too bluntly)  That is, if it's all right with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see how much we have to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy (puts her hand on her father's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: arm) Dad, this is what I really wanted to ask you....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew, knowing that she wants to talk to  her father alone, interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help yourself. (he turns and calls off) Oh, Tom, show this gentleman...   (he stops as he sees Tom is ready to leave)

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING TOM AT DOOR
dialogues.text: Tom is dressed in his street suit, ready to  go out.  Wynant stares at him in amazement. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy laughs, Wynant shamefacedly joins her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, forget it -- forget it.  Here ...  show this gentleman around... Tom beams at Wynant and starts to take his coat  and hat off as he speaks to Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right this way, sir. Andrew follows him out.

dialogues.speaker: WYNANT AND DOROTHY
dialogues.text: She pulls her father down beside her on a bench,  or possibly she climbs up on the long work  bench -- shoves the acetylene torches to a  distance -- and with her arms around him affec- tionately, continues: Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother's set her heart on a big church wedding. Wynant (parenthetically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate all that fuss.  But I'll do it on one  condition -- that you're there to give me away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would your mother say to that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be a little embarrassing ...  all of us  there ...  your other and me and your stepfather?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: for her stepfather)  He can stay home.  Please, Dad, won't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you think it'll be all right. (Dorothy jumps down from the bench  happily.  She kisses him, delighted to  have won him over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.  When is it going to be? I'm  leaving town tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a secret.  I can't even tell you, my dear.   I've got an important idea to work on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (then significantly, and with measured  tone) And I don't want anybody to steal it from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were planning to be married right after Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'll be back before Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one thing I won't forget.   (he looks at his watch)  Where's Macaulay?  I ought to be starting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy takes his watch while he starts to  take off his overalls.  There is an odd chain  attached to the watch, with links of gold,  copper, and silver.  As he slips off the  overalls, he speaks to Dorothy without looking  at her, trying to keep a casual note in his  voice.  CAMERA IS PANNING DURING THE SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your brother? Dorothy (she looks at her father

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: affectionately, sorry for him) He's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT -- as he goes to a washstand to  clean up a bit.  The basin is on the side  of the room.  The washstand could, if de- sired, be in a small closet, and the fol- lowing dialogue is played back and forth during this business. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to see him.  Why don't you bring him  down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dangling the watch chain)  You know how it is, Dad.  He's sort of under  Mother's thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watch -- winding it) You're not missing much.  He's cuckoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wynant comes back from the washstand -- CAMERA MOVING UP FOR A CLOSEUP ON THE TWO. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like all the rest of us. (he leans closer to Dorothy, speaking  humorously) Has this fellow... (he indicates Andrew with a nod  of his head) ...  has he seen the whole family? Dorothy (nodding and smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he still wants to marry me! Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a brave man. They look off as Andrew enters the shop again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew comes over to them with added interest  and admiration. Andrew (to Wynant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know you invented that Smelting Process. Dorothy (she holds the watch and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: chain toward Andrew) Look -- those are the first metals that came  through. (she indicates the links in the chain) Andrew looks interestedly at them as she  dangles the chain before him.  Wynant is  feeling his shin bone.  He gives a little  grunt of pain.  Dorothy turns sympathetically  to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Dad, does that still bother you? Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it isn't bad weather now. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better get home before it is. Dorothy (kissing Wynant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, darling.  Don't you dare forget...   December 30th. Wynant (to Andrew, with a warm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: friendliness) Goodbye, my boy.  Take care of Dorothy.  Show her  that there is such a thing as a happy marriage. Andrew (sincerely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do my best. Dorothy and Andrew start out, saying last  goodbyes to Wynant and Tom.  WE TRUCK ON THEM

dialogues.speaker: STAIRWAY FROM BASEMENT TO FIRST FLOOR -
Unknown
dialogues.text: All settled? (Dorothy nods) Grand! (then, after a second) Why did your mother ever divorce him?  He's swell. Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wel-l-l, it seems he has a secretary. Andrew (understanding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (he turns to Dorothy, smiling) I'll do my own typing! They have reached the top of the stairs now and  are in a long and narrow corridor, a service  elevator at one end, and a door leading to the  street at the other. Dorothy (looking to street ...  it is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: snowing) Dad's a good barometer... (she sees a taxi draw up in front of the  building) Quick! -- Here's a cab. They exit to street.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET
dialogues.text: It is a shabby, dreary street with warehouse  and a deserted brewery.  There is a driving  snow-storm.  Dorothy and Andrew come out as  the cab is pulling up at the curb, and with  difficulty against the wind and driving sleet,  they go forward ready to take it.  The cab  door opens and an umbrella comes out and is  opened, almost in their faces.  The umbrella  completely covers the upper part of the man  who is carrying it.  He turns to pay the driver.   Dorothy recognizes Macaulay and pulls up the  umbrella to speak to him under it. Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macaulay raises the umbrella, surprised.  He  is a fussy little bald-headed man of about  forty, wearing glasses.  He recognizes Dorothy  and beams. Macaulay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you? (then as the snow pelts down, he starts  to hold his umbrella over her) Here.  Get under this. Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks...  we're taking your cab. Dorothy climbs into the cab.  Andy follows  her.  She snuggles close against him, cold.   Macaulay hands the driver a bill. Macaulay (to Dorothy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your father still in there? Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he tell you where he was going? Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch-tch-tch -- (shutting the cab door) Well, goodbye, Miss Wynant. (then speaking to the driver as the  driver is giving him his change) You wouldn't drive slowly, so you don't get a tip. Driver (grinning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay -- I took it! He grins again and swings off, leaving  Macaulay looking down at the change in his  hand, indignant.  THEN WE PAN WITH HIM as  he enters the building. 9                 CORRIDOR FROM BASEMENT -- FULL SHOT. Wynant comes up the stairway and starts for  the service elevator as Macaulay comes in from  outside.  Wynant is now in a business suit,  but has no hat or overcoat on.  He doesn't see  Macaulay.  He pulls open the door of the  service elevator.  Macaulay starts to run to- ward Wynant with little fast steps, his bulky  umbrella hanging from his arm. Macaulay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Wynant...  Mr. Wynant! Wynant turns, his hand holding open the  elevator door. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, there! Come on up with me. Macaulay follows Wynant into the elevator,  panting a little.

dialogues.speaker: SERVICE ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Wynant pushes the button and the elevator  starts slowly up.  The elevator shaft is vis- ible through the wooden bars of the elevator.   Wynant stands looking down at Macaulay, amused  and friendly.   Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get my money? Macaulay (he pulls a wallet out of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his pocket and takes out a sheaf of new  bills.  He talks plaintively as he does so) I do wish you'd tell me where you're going. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But suppose some business comes up... Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just why I'm going. Macaulay starts to count out the bills into  Wynant's hand. Macaulay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred...  two hundred...  three... Wynant (takes the sheaf of bills,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you'd count them.  There's a thousand  dollars there. Wynant (stuffing them carelessly in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his pocket) I trust you. Macaulay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there anything else I can do for you? Have  you bought your ticket? Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gleam in his eye.  He sees a chance of  finding out where Wynant is going) Well, let me do that for you. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might do that.  Get me a ticket for... (he stops suddenly as he looks at Macaulay and sees the eager look in his eye -- realizes that he is about to give himself away) No, you don't! They smile at each other.  The elevator has reached the third floor by this time.  It stops.  Wynant gets out.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD FLOOR CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Macaulay prepares to follow Wynant, but  Wynant closes the door of the elevator, leaving him in it. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll I do if something comes up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Settle it yourself.  What have I got a lawyer for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Wynant reaches through the bar of the elevator door and pushes the button inside.  The elevator starts going down during the following dialogue. Macaulay stands inside, bewildered and worried. Macaulay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what if you need more money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left instructions with Julia.  She'll get it from you.  Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wynant strides out of the scene.  The elevator is beginning to disappear, carrying Macaulay. Macaulay (with his face upturned, he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: goes on pleading until he disappears out of  sight -- he is calling up) You don't tell me a thing.  I don't know where  you're going.  I don't know when you're coming back.   I don't know how to reach you if any business turns  up...! And the elevator goes down out of sight, his voice trailing as it does so.

dialogues.speaker: WYNANT --
dialogues.text: As we pick him up leaning down in front of a small safe, opening it.  He is talking to his  bookkeeper, Tanner, as he does so.  Tanner is  a little man with a quick eye and an eager  manner.  He has his hat and coat on prepara- tory to leaving for the day.  He is closing  and locking some cabinets as the scene ensues.   (Wynant's office is of a solid rather old- fashioned type such as would be found in a  building of this kind.  It should, in fact,  have windows through which a display room  given to machinery can be seen) Wynant (as he opens the safe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter's going to be married, Tanner.  Nice  young man.  She just brought him. Tanner listens preoccupied.  He seems a little nervous about Wynant looking in the safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to give her a wedding present.  Thought I'd better do it now, before I forget it.  I can drop them on my way to... (by this time Wynant has pulled out a and is puzzled to see it empty) That's funny.... (he leans down and hunts through the  different papers in the safe.  He doesn't  find what he wants.  He turns to Tanner) Where are those bonds? Tanner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I left them there. Tanner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Miss Wolf has them. Wynant (still worried -- wonders why

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia took them) Maybe she has. Tanner (picking up a baggage check

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from the table) You're forgetting the check for your suitcase. (Wynant takes it from him preoccupied) It's at the Grand Central. Wynant (still preoccupied)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes -- yes -- that's right -- (he goes out) As soon as Wynant goes out, Tanner looks after  him.  he seems worried.  He looks apprehen- sively back toward the safe.

dialogues.speaker: A RADIO IN A NEW YORK APARTMENT
dialogues.text: This is Julia Wolf's apartment, a fashionable penthouse furnished in very new modernistic style, but we do not reveal it as we dissolve in.  We are merely HOLDING ON THE RADIO AND A MAN -- JOE MORELLI -- who sits in front of it, in his shirt sleeves. Morelli is a tough  looking gangster.  He has the radio on.  He  is looking at a copy of Vogue.  A woman's  voice comes over the scene from off stage. Julia's Voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you want it? Morelli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight. (turning a page of Vogue -- holding  it up to the light.  Through the transparent  page, the corsets show through under the evening gowns.) Do women really wear them things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly there is the sound of a key in the door.  Morelli looks up quickly, his hand going to what we know is his gun, in his hip pocket --

dialogues.speaker: PROCESS GLASS.
dialogues.text: WE HOLD FOR A MOMENT as Morelli rises noise- lessly and stands there, alert and ready for  anyone.  NOW CAMERA SWINGS RAPIDLY OVER TO THE: 15                DOOR -- CLOSE SHOT ON WYNANT. As he enters, having used his own key.  He still seems occupied, and doesn't see Morelli as he  comes through.  CAMERA SWINGS RAPIDLY BACK TO: 16                CLOSEUP ON MORELLI -- BEFORE THE RADIO. He stands there, quietly menacing, his hand on his hip. Morelli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in the wrong place, mister.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH WYNANT
dialogues.text: Wynant looks off at him, surprised and angry. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: FLASH MORELLI
dialogues.text: AS WE PAN HIM FORWARD a few steps.  He gives Wynant a savage double-O. Morelli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's on your mind? What do you want? Julia's Voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching Wynant) That's what I want to know. 19                MEDIUM SHOT -- THE APARTMENT. As Julia comes into the room, with two drinks  in her hand.  She is a woman of about thirty.   She is in very elaborate lounging pajamas,  her hair is too well waved, her nails too red,  her eyebrows too delicately arched.  But she  has the look of a hard businesswoman under- neath it all.  She looks disturbed as she sees  it is Wynant. Julia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're just having a little drink. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) So I see. Morelli looks from one to the other.  In Wynant's attitude of displeased propietorship, he gets his hint of who he is.  he reaches for his coat over the chair and starts to put it on. Julia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her eyes still on Wynant) See you later, Joe. Morelli looks from one to the other, and then  slowly gets his hat and starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  I didn't know I was talking to the boy friend.  S'long. He walks carelessly and arrogantly out of  the door, slamming it after him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: AND WYNANT.  She puts the drinks down. She tries to ignore Wynant's very evident displeasure. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not anybody.  Just a fellow I used to know. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd given up that sort of friend. Julia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the first time I've seen him in years.  I didn't want him to think I was high-hatting him. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving over to him, trying to  conciliate him) Don't worry.  You won't see him again. (she tries to take Wynant's coat and  hat) What happened? Did you change your mind about  going? Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I just came back for a second.  I wanted to get those bonds. Julia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she controls her fear under an air  of ignorance) What bonds? Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The government bonds.  The ones you took from the  office safe. Julia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smoothly lying) Oh yes.  Why, you told me to sell them a long time  ago. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a level tone) I'd never tell you to sell those.  I bought them for my daughter. Julia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting her) Now see here, Julia.  You're counting a little too  much on my being absent-minded.  You've been taking  a little here and there for some time, and I haven't  said anything about it.  But this is fifty thousand dollars! Julia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flying into a temper to try to hide her guilt) Do you realize that you're accusing me of .... Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one else had the combination of that safe.  You took them.  What did you do with them? Julia (in a fury)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I did take them? I'm sick and tired of  seeing you hand out thousands of dollars to that  family of yours.... Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going on without listening to him) -- supporting that gang of loafers! There's not one of them that cares a damn for you.  A wife who threw you out the first time your foot slipped.  They wouldn't raise a hand to help you.  And I've given my whole life for you.  If you kicked off tomorrow, where'd I be? Out in the gutter! (then defiantly) Sure I took those bonds.  Who has a better right -- ? WE HOLD A MOMENT.   There is a slight pause, then Wynant quietly, and unheeding all that she has said, starts for the phone.  WE PAN HIM OVER AND HOLD as he picks up the phone (but not the receiver as yet) and speaks off to Julia: Wynant (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want that money right now, or I'll hand you over  to the police. Julia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.  -- not believing that he will do it) Go ahead! Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifts phone from receiver now -- still quietly) They'll be pretty rough with you....with your record. CAMERA PULLS BACK, and Julia hurries into the  scene. Julia (contemptuous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thats a fine thing to throw up to me after all  I've been to you....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello ....  give me .... (Julia grabs the telephone from him, in a fury.  She puts it down.  Puts the re- ceiver in place.  They stand facing each other) Well ....  ? Julia (in a surly tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give it back to you ....  all I've got .... twenty-five thousand .... Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he takes her by the wrists, gripping her  hard, trying to force the truth from her) You're going to return every cent of it! Julia (flashing again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't! I haven't got it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do with the rest? Julia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never had it. The telephone rings. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then someone was in with you.  Who was it? -- Who was it? (Julia makes a move to answer the phone which rings again insistently) I'll answer that -- (he picks up the phone) Hello ...  hello ...

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE BOOTH
dialogues.text: A weasel-faced little man, Nunheim, is in the booth at the phone, but as he hears Wynant's voice say "hello", he very quietly pulls down the hook for the receiver and places the re- ceiver gently on it.  He turns away.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Wynant is clicking the receiver up and down,  as he repeats several times, sharply: Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello ...  hello ...  hello ...  HELLO .... Then, evidently hearing the sound of the re- ceiver being replaced, he impatiently puts the  telephone down and turns back to Julia. Wynant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to tell me.  I have a pretty good idea. And with this WE PAN HIM as he puts on his hat and starts to walk out of the apartment -- with determination and a menacing purpose in his face. Julia (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Wynant turns at the door and smiles - a terrify- ing smile - and walks out.  The CAMERA SWINGS QUICKLY BACK TO JULIA.  She looks after him terrified as we

dialogues.speaker: A STREET AT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Wynant strides down the street, his long, lean, narrow form casting a long shadow on the snowy pavement.  THE CAMERA HOLDS IN A  RUNNING SHOT ON THE SHADOW as it elongates still further, and finally disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (NOTE: We should get the above shadow effect  through heavy snow, (via reflection of street  lamps).  The idea and mood here of the shadow  of the "thin man" as it strides rapidly through  the night is purposely intended for a necessary  effect.)

dialogues.speaker: A CHRISTMAS WREATH.
dialogues.text: The wreath is enormous, and under the conven- al greeting: "A MERRY CHRISTMAS", which is in silver across it, there is a current uncon- ventional greeting also in silver, which reads: (This slogan to come)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On sound track behind the shot an orchestra is playing gaily.  Possibly an arrangement that Lombardo would make on "JINGLE BELLS, JINGLE  BELLS".  There is also the sound of gay chat- ter and jingles of many cocktail shakers.  NOW

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA PULLS BACK TO REVEAL THE BAR OF A
dialogues.text: SPEAKEASY, or, to be more up to date, the bar  of a Biltmore or a Waldorf Astoria Hotel.  It was against the glass of the bar that the  Christmas wreath was first shown.  It is about three o'clock in the afternoon.  Almost all of the people sitting on the high stools in front of the bar are women.  Several bartenders are shaking cocktails.  The music, which, by the way, comes from an adjoining tea dansant room,  continues.  There is a holiday air about the whole place.  A sophistication and a gaiety  belonging to thirsty New York of the present  moment.  CAMERA RUNS DOWN THE LINE OF THE BAR  AND HOLDS AT THE END, where a bartender is placing two cocktails on a tray held by a  waiter.  WE TRUCK ON THE WAITER as he takes the tray into the adjoining room.  The room is quite filled with the afternoon tango crowd, and several couples are danicng on the floor.  WE HOLD as the waiter stops at a small  table along the wall.  Dorothy and Andrew are seated there.  Dorothy is looking very glum. Andrew (putting his hand on hers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Dorothy tries to smile, but it's a dreary attempt.  The waiter puts down the cock- tails and leaves. Andrew (holds up his glass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to us! He drinks his cocktail.  Dorothy takes a sip of hers.  Andrew goes on talking, trying to get her out of the doldrums. Andrew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time next year, we'll be two old married people ...  trimming the tree ...  hanging up the stock- ings for the children ... (then as she looks up) ...  well, the child, then. Dorothy tries to smile, but she is worried, and cannot enter into his fun.  She puts her drink down. Andrew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, darling ...  not sweet enough? Dorothy (listlessly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. (NOTE TO VAN: If you want them to get up and  join the dancers, it can be done at this  point.  After Dorothy says, "It's all right",  Andrew says, "Come on, let's dance.  I've got  to get you out of the dumps somehow" -- and  pulls her to her feet.  The following scene  continues now, as follows, in a PANNING SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning forward -- serious now) Darling, your father's all right.  He'll turn up in time. Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns to him -- suddenly distraught) But tonight is Christmas Eve! Andrew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just forgotten.  You know he forgets everything. Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's never forgotten a promise to me.  I'm worried about him.  I know something's happened to him. She looks off scene toward the bar.  Suddenly her attention is riveted on someone. Andrew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What could happen to him, darling? You mustn't worry.... (then as he half rises, he continues) What is it? Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute... She leaves the table -- her eyes still fixed eagerly on the man she has seen.  WE TRUCK AND PAN WITH HER as she goes forward to the  bar.  And as she comes in, we see her re- act eagerly as she confronts a good-looking man of about thirty-five, tall, casual, and worldly wise, who is standing in front of the  bar, his face reflected in the mirror.  This is NICK CHARLES. Nick (to the bartender)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick Charles turns to her.  He smiles at her. He hasn't the faintest idea who she is, but he's not going to discourage such a pretty  girl.   Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very cordially) Hello! (then over his shoulder to the bartender) Make it two! (then back to Dorothy) How are you? Dorothy realizes that he hasn't any remem- brance of her. Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, we know each other. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartily) Of course we do! We've been friends for years. Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inspecting him) Aren't you Nick Charles? Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his face changes.  He realizes that she does know him) Yes. Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't remember me.....  I'm Dorothy Wynant. The bartender sets the drinks on the bar before Nick, who looks at Dorothy puzzled, trying to realize that this is the child  he used to know. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that scrawny little....? (he puts out his hand as if measuring a little girl's height) Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you ever remember me? Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intently) I was fascinated with you....  a real live detec- tive....  You used to tell me the most wonderful  stories.  Were they true? Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably not. Andrew comes up to them.  Dorothy turns to introduce him. Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy...  this is Nick Charles.  He worked on a case  for father. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking hands with Andrew) Yes.  Some nut who wanted to kill him. (then to Dorothy) How is your father? Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I was going to ask you.  he's dis- appeared! Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't say that -- he's just off somewhere work- ing. Dorothy (to Nick)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't find him.  I've tried everything.  I thought you might know. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) I don't know anything -- I've been in California for four years.  What about his lawyer? Used to be a guy named Mac-- something. Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you try him again? Andy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (digging in his pocket) Here's a nickle. Andrew gives her a nickle and she goes off. Now that she has gone Andrew drops his  pretense of minimizing her father's failure  to appear.  he steps up close to Nick. Andrew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got me worrying, too. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily, as he reaches for his cocktail) (NOTE: During the entire play, Nick is always reaching for a cocktail!) Don't start worrying about him.  He's a good guy, but screwy. Andrew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed by what he has just heard) Why did that man want to kill him? Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said he stole his invention. Andrew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you suppose.....  ? The bartender is placing more drinks in  front of Nick. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deciding he is silly to get  so worried) Nothing. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better take a drink. He hands him one of the cocktails. As they start to drink, a commotion is heard offscene ...  a dog barking ...  men's voices raised in protestation ...  and a a woman's voice above it all.  It is NORA, Nick's wife. Nora's Voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Asta! Where are you going? Asta! Bartenders, as well as Nick and Andrew,  look off toward the commotion.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLOAK ROOM OR CORRIDOR.
dialogues.text: NORA CHARLES, Nick's wife, is coming through. She is a woman of about twenty-six...  a tre- mendously vital person, interested in every- body and everything, in contrast to Nick's  apparent indifference to anything except when  he is going to get his next drink.  There is a  warm understanding relationship between them.   They are really crazy about each other, but  undemonstrative and humorous in their compan- ionship.  They are tolerant, easy-going, taking  drink for drink, and battling their way to- gether with a dry humor.  Just now Nora has  been shopping.  Her arms are full of small  packages.  Her hat is askew.  She is pulled  along bodily by a small white Sealingham on a  leash.  A doorman and a hat-check clerk are  following her, protesting at her bringing the  dog into this fashionable hotel.  The dog is  exitedly barking. Doorman

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame, you can't bring that dog in here! Nora

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not bringing him.  He's bringing me! (then to the dog) Asta!  Asta! But the dog pays no attention.  He pulls her  like a streak out of the scene toward the bar.   Nora's packages are left in a trail behind her  as she stumbles after him.  The attendants  follow after her, picking up the parcels and  protesting vehemently. Attendants

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Madame...  dogs aren't allowed.... It isn't only your dog...  but if we started.... Madame, you dropped your package....  etc.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: As Asta, the dog, rushes in, still with Nora  on the other end of the leash.  The dog makes  a bee-line for Nick, pulls away and -- ker- plunk! -- he leaps clear up into Nick's arms.   He is barking with delight.  He seems to have  a particular desire to lick Nick's nose.  Nora,  more dishevelled than ever and breathless,  enters, panting.  She realizes that this was  Asta's objective. Nora

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's you he was after! Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the dog) He's dragged me into every gin mill on the block. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in explanation) I had him out this morning. Nora

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought so.  He even tried to drag me into the  gentlemen's -- Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping her to introduce Andrew) Oh, this is Andy -- Nora and Andy smile at each other. Nora

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're you, Andy? (hastening to add) I don't usually look this way, but I've been Christmas shopping. One of the attendants who followed Nora comes up.  He hands Nora several of her packages. Attendant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame, I'm afraid you'll have to.... Nick (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Joe.  It's my dog... (and as an afterthought, waving  his hand at Nora) ....and my wife. Nora

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might have mentioned me first. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joe) He's well-trained.  He'll behave himself. Nora

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as there isn't a fire hydrant.  What I've  gone through -- Attendant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's all right. (He puts Asta down on the floor. He speaks to the dog) Now lie down. (Asta looks up at him, wagging his tail, but making no move to obey him.  Nick speaks with more authority) Lie down! (still Asta looks fondly up at him, with- out obeying) Well then, stand up! (then triumphantly to Joe) See? The attendant laughs and moves off. Dorothy comes toward them from the telephone booth.  She seems a little more cheerful.  Andrew  watches her anxiously. Andrew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just around the corner. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  The lawyer -- I'm going to see him. Nick realizes that Dorothy and his wife have not met.  He makes the introduction very casually, waving his hand to indicate Nora. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my wife -- Dorothy Wynant. The two women smile in acknowledgment.  nora looks at Dorothy with warm interest. Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?  I'm sorry we have to rush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're at the Normandie for a couple of weeks.  Why don't you drop around? Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye. The two go quickly off.  Nora looks after them. Nora

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you like 'em like that. Nora (grinning at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only you, darling...  lanky brunettes with wicked  jaws. Nora

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping I wouldn't have to tell you.  Dorothy is really my daughter.  You see, it was Spring in Venice, and I was so young.  I didn't know what I was doing.  We were all like that on my father's  side. Nora

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, how is your father's side? Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many drinks have you had? Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six Martinis. Nora (to the waiter, ordering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six Martinis. (then to Nick) You're not going to have anything on me. As she hugs the bar, her foot on the rail, in imitation of Nick

dialogues.speaker: AN ICE BAG.
dialogues.text: Nick's hands are screwing the cover on the ice bag.  CAMERA PULLS BACK TO reveal him in the bathroom of his suite at the Normandie. He has just filled the bag from the wash basin which is full of ice.  THE CAMERA  TRUCKS with him as he goes into the bedroom and over to the bed. 28                CLOSE UP OF ASTA. He is sitting on the foot of the bed, his head cocked, looking anxiously at Nora at the other side of the bed. 29                CLOSE SHOT - AT BED. Nora is lying on the bed, dressed as we saw her in the last scene, except for her hat. Nick comes in and puts the ice bag on her head.  Nora opens her eyes and speaks feebly to Nick. Nora

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What hit me? Nick (grinning at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That last Martini. Asta, delighted that Nora is all right, rushes  to her, and licks her face. Nora (struggling to get up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't lie here.  I've got to get up and trim that darned Christmas tree. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy. The doorbell of the apartment rings.  Nick starts into the next room.  Nora looks off perturbed.  She doesn't feel up to visitors. Nora

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that? Nick (as he walks out)

dialogues.speaker: WINDOWS
dialogues.text: In one corner of the living room is an enor- mous Christmas tree, without any ornaments on it.  The room is a mass of boxes and excelsior. Nick comes from the bedroom and opens the outer room.  Macaulay stands outside, his eyes blinking behind their glasses, in friendly wel- come.  CAMERA MOVES UP FOR CLOSE SHOT ON THE TWO. Macaulay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you? Nick (he is surprised but recognizes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: him after a second and is cordial) Hello, Macaulay.  Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy told me you were here.  I was going to  telephone but.... Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right.  What are you drinking? WE PAN Nick over to a table where there are bottles of Scotch and ice and syphons of seltzer. Macaulay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, thank you.  Nothing. (Nick pours himself a drink as Macaulay sits down) I wanted to see you...  What's Mimi up to, Charles? Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mimi? (for a minute he doesn't realize who  Mimi is) ...  Oh, Dorothy's mother.  Does she have to be up  to something? Macaulay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She usually is.  Trying one way or another to get  money out of Wynant.  I wanted to find out if you  were er - er - (he hints for the word) --sleuthing for her. Nick (dryly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been a detective for four years. Macaulay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pressing syphon of seltzer) My wife's father died and left her a lumber mill and a narrow guage railroad and a couple of other  things.  And I'm looking after them. Macaulay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.  I see. Nick (coming over to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all the fuss about? Is he in hiding? Macaulay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know as much about it as I do.  I haven't  seen him in three months. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sends word through Julia Wolf when he wants  money...  I give it to her and she gives it to  him. The telephone rings.  Nick goes over to it, speaking to Macaulay as he goes. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's still on? (he picks up the phone) Nora's Voice (o.s.)(she has

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: answered the phone in the next room) Hello....  just a minute. Nick, who has listened on the phone, holds it out toward Macaulay. Nick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for you. (Macaulay gets up and starts for the phone) Your office. Macaulay takes the telephone.  Nora appears  in the doorway to the bedroom.  She has a box  of Christmas tree ornaments in her hand.  The  ice bag is tied on her head, slightly askew.   She is followed by Asta. Nora

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a Mr. Macaulay in the house? (she looks over and sees Macaulay at the  phone) Oh, it's you. Macaulay (into the telephone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he turns to Nora.  In his desire to be  polite, he almost misses both the intro- duction to Nora, and his telephone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do? (he turns hastily back to the telephone. Nora walks out of the scene, toward the Xmas tree) What did you say?....  He is?....  Where is he?  Very well. (he hangs up and turns to Nick)  He's back in town.... (then as Nick looks mystified, he adds:)  Wynant.  Thank heaven.  He's waiting for me now.   (then realizing that Nora doesn't know  what he is talking about)  Forgive me, Mrs. Charles...  but I've been so upset.   It's no joke working for a man like that.  I must be off.   (he starts for the door, which Nick opens  for him)  Goodbye....  goodbye,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macaulay shuts the door after him only to  open it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the above, Nora has started to decorate  the tree.  She is standing on a chair, a  couple of Xmas ornaments in her hand, reach- ing toward the top or the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anyone says "Merry Christmas" once more, I'll  kill 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick starts to the telephone directory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IГ­m going to telephone that poor kid.   (he searches in the directory for a  number)  At least she'll be glad to know he's alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asta is sniffing around the bottom of the  tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has two different ornaments in her  hand, trying to decide which to put on the  top of the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I use this....  or this? (she looks down at Asta, who is out of   sight.  She speaks sharply) Asta! Asta! (she returns to her trimming, muttering  indignantly) Our nice Christmas tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has dialed his number.  He speaks into the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mimi Jorgensen, formerly Mrs. Clyde Wynant,  is at the phone.  She is a slightly faded,  but still very pretty woman of about forty- one or two.  She is utterly feminine, with bright, little ways of talking and moving.  She distrusts all women, even her daughter Dorothy, and treats all men with a flirtatious condes- cension, as if they were children.  The only  thing she really has any emotion about is her  present husband, who she adores.  She is  terrified that he will leave her, knowing,  although she won't admit it, that he married  her for her money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room of her expensive apartment  reflects her personality.  It is a modernized Victorian, full or alabaster lamps, curved  soft chairs and gleaming satin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mimi is answering the telephone.  Dorothy  stands in the doorway, listening to her  mother as she takes off her hat and coat.  She  is dressed in the same clothes in which we  saw her at the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she hears that it is Nick Charles, her  voice takes on a flirtatious note)  How are you?....  Oh, I'm Mrs. Jorgensen now....   (she sees Dorothy out of the corner of  her eye, but pretends that she doesn't  know she is there)  No, she isn't here. (Dorothy moves toward the telephone)  Is it about her father?  Well, can I take the message? Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the phone from her mother) Give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone, pretending surprise) Oh, here she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly she gives the phone to Dorothy.   She stands close to Dorothy, trying to hear  the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to relieve your mind.  Your father's  alive and all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her face lights up with relief) Oh, thank heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? Has he found him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: attention to her mother) Do you know where he's living? (for a moment she cannot help but feel hurt) Oh.... (then she realizes how selfish her feeling  is) Well, at least I'm glad he's all right.  Thank you for calling.  Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up.  Mimi eagerly questions her,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilbert comes into the room.  He is a boy of about seventeen or eighteen.  He wears  spectacles.  He is slight in build.  The two  women don't notice him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That isn't true.  It was about your father.  Where  is he? Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's all right.  Isn't that enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just want money -- and you haven't any right to  any more.  He made a big settlement on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's gone long ago.  I've got to see him.  Where  is he? Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't have you hounding him any more for money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you. Dorothy (turning on him acccusingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been listening again on that extension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  What's an extension for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: her favorite of the two children) What is it, Gilbert? Tell mother! What did he  say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said that father's in town.  He's been seeing  Julia right along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could tell you where father is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother ....  you couldn't do that.  You couldn't go to her. Mimi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say I would.  But we've got to have money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy  Did it ever occur to you that Chris might work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the sofa a man rises with languid  dignity.  It is Chris Jorgensen.  He is  younger than Mimi.  A very handsome man, but  one whom you could know at first sight that  you could not trust. Mimi's Voice (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jorgensen pays no attention to Mimi.  He  throws Dorothy a deadly glance and walks with  hurt dignity out of the room, carrying the  newspaper he has been reading.  CAMERA PULLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mimi looks after Jorgensen, fearfully.  She  turns to Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hurries out of the room after Jorgensen.   Dorothy looks after them, disgusted.  Gilbert  watches Dorothy with detached, scientific  interest. Gilbert

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you have an Oedipus complex and you won't  admit it. Dorothy (this is the last straw)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts out of the room but Gilbert con- tinues to talk to her, although she is not  paying any attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trouble with you is that you won't face facts.   I know I have a mother fixation...  but it's  slight......  it hasn't yet reached the point of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy walks out.  Gilbert looks after her,  bewildered by her lack or scientific interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jorgensen is standing in front of the mirror, adjusting his tie.  Mimi comes in, very much perturbed.  She goes to him affectionately.   Jorgensen realizes his power over her and  uses it. Mimi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind what she says, Chris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I help but mind? I'm constantly humiliat- ed...  just because I haven't money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you go to see Julia?  She handles his money. Mimi (protesting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't go near that woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up his hat and coat from a chair.   Mimi watches him anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what I said I'd do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't do that...  you wouldn't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jorgensen strides out of the door and down  the hall.  Mimi comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Chris pays no attention.  Mimi, distrait,  goes back into his room.  As she closes the door, we see Gilbert come out from behind the open door, where he has been listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mimi stands irresolute for a minute, then  goes to the telephone and dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wolfe?  Well this is Mrs. Jorgensen...  I  wonder if I may see you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia is evidently very much startled by Mrs.  Jorgensen's calling her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts down the telephone, thinking hard,  worried by the idea or Mrs. Jorgensen's impend- ing visit.  Suddenly she makes up her mind  and hastily dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: MIMI'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Mimi gets up from the telephone.  There is a  look of grim determination on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a clerk, standing behind the desk, and  a telephone operator at a small switchboard.   Mimi is standing in front of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is Miss Wolfe's apartment number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine A. Mimi turns and walks across the lobby.  The  CAMERA TRUCKS with her.  As she goes toward the elevator, Albert Nunheim is seen coming  down the last steps of the stairs, out of her sight.  He is a weasel-faced, little man with a long nose, weak mouth, and a shifty look in his eye.  The clerk's voice comes over the SOUND TRACK calling after Mimi. Clerk's Voice (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mimi says "Miss Wolfe", Nunheim stiffens  and pulls back against the wall.  He waits there until he hears the sound of the elevator  door closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is evidently terrified by something that  he has seen.  He waits to be sure that Mimi has gone up in the elevator and then, with a  furtive glance at the desk, CAMERA PULLS BACK  AND PANS WITH HIM as he sneaks out and down  the stairs on the other side of the elevator  shaft leading down to the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mimi gets out of the elevator and goes to the door of the apartment 9-A across the hall.   She rings the doorbell.  There is no response. She rings again, a lock or grim determination  on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunheim comes out of the entrance, looks  furtively up and down the street.  He takes out a cigarette, lights it, and then, with a  pretense of being casual, walks off down the  street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting no response to her ringing, Mimi is  knocking on the door.  She is furious with  Julia for not letting her in.  Still getting  no answer, she tries the door.  She is sur- prised to find it is open.  She looks up and  down the hall and then decides to investigate.   She walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mimi comes into the room.  She shuts the door  slowly behind her.  She looks curiously around  the room, interested to see what kind of a  place her ex-husband has furnished for Julia.   Seeing no one in the room, she goes through it  toward the bedroom.  As she gets to the door  and looks curiously in, she stiffens and screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the floor of the ornate bedroom, Julia  Wolfe's dead body lies, stretched out.  She has been shot.  She is dressed as she was when she answered Mimi's telephone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a minute, Mimi stands in the doorway look- ing down at the body, rooted to the spot with  horror.  Then she looks around for the tele- phone, sees it beside the bed, and rushes  to it, CAMERA PANNING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick! Quick! Send somebody up here right away. Something terrible has happened!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She replaces the receiver.  For a second, she stands still, her back to the body.  But her  curiosity finally overcomes her terror, and  she goes slowly back toward the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands looking down at Julia, a million  speculations and suspicions going through her   mind.  Suddenly her eye fastens on something in the dead woman's outflung hand. Her eyes widen with horror.  She makes up her mind to  take the object, which we do not see. Look- ing around quickly to see if no one has come  in, she reaches down, takes it from the girl's  hand, and stuffs it in her hand bag.  She straightens up, CAMERA PANNING QUICKLY UP FOR:

dialogues.speaker: MIMI.
dialogues.text: She stands clutching her bag, her eyes wide  with horror at the realization of what that  piece of evidence means.  She is trying to  formulate a plan of action as we:

dialogues.speaker: HOMICIDE BUREAU
dialogues.text: Several officers are sitting around talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way these dames get by with things makes me   sick. The telephone rings.  Another officer answers  the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? -- Julia Wolfe, 145 West 55. (as he hears the address he writes it down) 1st Officer (sitting up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me. 2nd Officer (he replaces the re-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ceiver and turns to the other officer) Here you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives the officer the paper. 1st Officer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macaulay is sitting at a flat desk, with some  papers in front of him.  A stenographer is tak- ing dictation.  The inter-office communicator buzzes.  Macaulay leans over pulls the switch and listens.  A girl's voice comes over the communicator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macaulay (frowning in annoyance at the interrupt-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tion) Who is it?  Girl's Voice (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a puzzled frown, Macaulay picks up the phone. Macaulay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... (then with an awed surprise) Murdered! ...  Yes, yes, I'll be right over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in a booth at a speakeasy.  Marian  is a big-boned, full-fleshed, red-haired wo- man of about twenty-eight, handsome in a  rather brutal, sloppy way.  Nunheim has a satisfied smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you been? A waiter comes and puts two beers in front  of them.  He stands waiting to be paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marian gives him a dirty look and takes a  quarter out of her purse and throws it down  to pay the waiter for the beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two old wispy cleaning women in aprons with  pass keys on thin belts are standing talking  with their heads together outside of Julia's apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost whispering)  What're you goin' to tell 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wiping her forehead with a dust cloth)  I guess you got to tell 'em everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know's they had an awful fight a while ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police officer comes to the door of the  apartment.  He beckons to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without realizing the humor of the "girls",  they start in.

dialogues.speaker: STUDSY'S CABARET
dialogues.text: It is in a flashy Broadway cabaret.  On the  dance floor about ten girls in practice  clothes are rehearsing a new routine.  A man  is mechanically playing the piano for them. Several waiters are decorating the room with greens and Christmas wreaths.  It is late  afternoon, and the place has no customers in it.  The chairs are piled on the tables.   Morelli is sitting at a table.  The waiter is  placing a bottle of Scotch and a glass before  him.  Studsy comes up to the table.  Studsy  is a powerfully built man of about fifty who looks forty.  He is a little fat now, but not  soft.  Morelli looks up as he comes to the table.  CAMERA MOVES UP FOR CLOSE SHOT ON  THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to pour a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Morelli very closely) Diden you know Julia Wolfe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a guarded tone in his voice) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody just bumped her off  I thought you'd like to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Studsy walks away.  Morelli slowly drinks his liquor, his eyes fixed on space, think- ing hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Medical Examiner, Dr. Walton, is leaning  over Julia's body.  An officer is sitting in front of Julia's desk, looking through her  papers and letters and throwing them to one  side as he reads them.  John Guild, a burly,  laconic, Special Investigator is in charge of the investigation.  He is questioning  Macaulay, who is sitting facing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was the last time you gave her money for  Wynant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday.  I gave her a thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling over his shoulder to the other  officer at the desk) Seen any signs of it, Bill? Bill

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aand her with that sparkler on her hand, and thirty  dollars in her purse?  Looks to me like our  friend Wynant came to collect and ran into a little trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say downstairs they haven't seen him in three months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) There's a lot of things they don't see in this place. (he turns back to Macaulay)  And you say you haven't seen him or heard from him  in that time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meticulously honest)  I said he hadn't written me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, then you did hear from him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he hesitates to tell something which  seems to incriminate Wynant) Well....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't in.  My secretary took the message.  He  left word for me to meet him at the Plaza. Guild

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  But he didn't show up.   An officer comes from the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Guild)  His house and his shop is closed.  And he ain't  at any hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) You're not going to stop at that, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer goes out again.  Guild turns back to Macaulay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly defending Wynant)  I know he'll turn up as soon as he sees this in the papers.  You can't think he had anything to do with it, Mr. Guild.  He wasn't the kind of man  that....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Do you know what they fought about that night he went away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning as he realizes that this  sounds bad)  I didn't know they had a fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissing Macaulay) Well, thanks.  We'll call you when we need you  again.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: He is leaning over Julia's body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Guild, here's something very interesting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Guild walks into the shot, we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mimi is in the midst of telling her experience. Gilbert, Dorothy and Jorgensen are listening.   Mimi still has her hat and coat on.  She has  just come in.  She is seated, on the edge of her chair, enjoying the recital.  Jorgensen stands at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ---- and there she was lying dead.  The police said  she'd probably been killed about ten minutes before I got there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning around - speaking with  quiet anger)  I thought you said you weren't going there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who is tremendously interested)  Did they find any clues...  a gun or fingerprints or anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very glibly -  remembering what  she has in her purse)  Not a thing.   Gilbert

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense! She got at she deserved.   Gilbert

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mimi, not accusingly, but with  scientific detached interest) Did you kill her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? You had a perfectly good motive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you won't talk that way to the police when they come here.

dialogues.speaker: JORGENSEN.
dialogues.text: There is a guarded look of terror in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police.  I thought you said they'd finished with you. Mimi's voice (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said they'd finished for the present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thought that the police might come to the apartment increases his fear.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY AND GILBERT.
dialogues.text: Mimi is watching Jorgensen anxiously.   Gilbert

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got my alibi.  I was at the Public Library. (To Jorgensen) Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hastily, with her eyes still on Jorgensen)  Children, will you go into the next room? I want to  talk to Chris alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that minute the front door bell rings.   Mimi looks toward the door, wondering who  it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going out to answer the ring) I'll go. Jorgensen

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY OUTSIDE JORGENSEN APARTMENT.
dialogues.text: Guild and Bill are standing outside the  door of the Jorgensen's apartment.  Gilbert  opens the door of the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted to see then) Yes, come right in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two officers go in and the door closes  behind them.  From a door beyond, the service  door of the apartment, Jorgensen comes out, putting on his hat and coat as he comes.  He doesn't wait for the elevator but starts  down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guild is seated uncomfortably on one of  Mimi's delicate chairs, opposite Mimi.   Gilbert is standing, listening eagerly.   Dorothy sits nearby, her mind deeply  occupied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mimi is a little frightened, but she hides  it under a pretense of wanting to do all she can to help.  Dorothy sits listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as scene picks up) There are a few things we want to check up on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say you were in the room with the body  from the time you discovered it 'til we came?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see anything in Miss Wolfe's hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you didn't leave the room...  that one  of the bellhops or maids might not have been  in there alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing at the opening he has given her) I don't think so.  Of course I was terribly  upset...  I hardly knew what I was doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Medical Examiner seems to think that the body  was touched.  He says it looks as if the girl's  hand had been forced open after she was killed....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we just found out she had a thousand dollars  the night before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy looks toward her Mother, her eyes  wide with horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I can't help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guild rises and starts for the door.  Bill  turns to follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. (slight pause -- His eyes swiftly scrutinize the group) Well, we'll be going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guild and the officer go out.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY OUTSIDE JORGENSEN APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Guild and Bill come out, followed by Gilbert. Guild goes to the elevator and rings the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I go down and see the body? I've never  seen a dead body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (for a minute he is curious, thinking  there may be some reason) Why do you want to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very serious) I've been studying psychopathic criminology.  I  have a theory.  Perhaps this as the work of a  sadist or a paranoiac.  If I saw it, I might be  able to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pretending to be as serious as Gilbert) That's a good idea.  But don't you bother to come down.  We'll bring the body right up here.   (he gets into the elevator)  Come on, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They leave Gilbert, uncertain whether he  is being kidded or whether they mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is closed behind her.  She goes to a small wall safe and opens it.  Then she opens her bag and is about to put the thing  she took from Julia's hand wrapped in a  handkerchief, into the safe, when she is  startled by Dorothy's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she turns in the direction of Dorothy's voice) None of your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy comes up to her mother and speaks  accusingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took that money from Julia's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy  Then what are you hiding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with malicious relish)  It's a piece of evidence that's worth a great  deal more than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with bitter contempt for her other)  You hand that over to the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do nothing of the sort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then.  I'll tell them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very sure of her ground) I don't think you will.  It's your father's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked)  I don't believe it! You're lying!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (viciously pleased at breaking  Dorothy's faith in her father) There! She holds out the broken end of the watch  chain that we saw Wynant carry, wrapped in  a handkerchief which is spotted with blood. Dorothy looks at it, and recognizes it  with horror. Dorothy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is eight o'clock the same night...  about two hours later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a party in full swing.  It is an odd assortment of people.  There is a police cap- tain there, a reminder of Nick's old life.   A little prizefight manager with a big  fighter in tow.  Quinn, a dissipated looking  man of about thirty-five, and his wife, a  rather faded woman of about thirty-two, very jealous of Friend Husband.  Quinn is a broker, and the only one in evening clothes.  Then  there is Foster, a big fat man, who sits near the radio, a glass in his hand.  With every  sip, he grows more sentimental, as he lis- tens to the program of Christmas carols that  are coming over the radio.  There is an  improvised bar with everything in the way of liquors and necessary accompaniments on  it.  Nick is moving among the people, seeing that they are served.  Nick goes over to  Mrs. Quinn, giving her one of the drinks he is carrying.  Mrs. Quinn is looking  around rather fearfully at the curious  assortment of people in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving her a drink) How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around disapprovingly) Who are they, Nick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles and passes on to another group.   Among them is a very rough looking man with  a battered face.  He turns to grin at Nick  showing a mouth with several teeth missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Nick.  I think your wife's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  I wanted you to see her...  and I wanted her  to see you. Nick goes on to speak to the Police Captain  who is standing talking to a very distin- guished looking woman, in evening clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nick)  It's like old times, Nick.  Remember the fun  we used to have when we were both flat broke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sentimental sigh) Those were the good old days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't kid yourself.  These are the good old days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick goes on his way to another group.   The CAMERA PANS OVER TO NORA at the door.   She opens it to admit Face Peppler.  He is a tough-looking ex-convict.  He looks eagerly  around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pat on the posterior) He's a good guy. (his eyes are eagerly searching the room for Nick) He sent me up the river once. (he sees Nick coming toward him, and with the greatest good will and enthusiasm, he greets him) Hey, Nick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long time I don't see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know.  That time he caught me was a accident.  I led with my right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Peppler by the arm out of the  scene as WE PAN NORA TO THE TELEPHONE.  She  picks up the receiver, her eyes on the odd  mixture of people assembled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother to announce any more.  Just send any- body right up.   (then as the clerk evidently tries to  protect her)  I know.  But it's all right.  They're his friends,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick is pouring a drink for Face.  The little  prizefight manager comes up to him with a  great hulk of a fighter in tow.  (The contrast  in sizes is amusing.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like to buy a piece of this pug, Nick? I'll sell  you twenty-five percent of him for five grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been knocking 'em cold.  He ain't afraid of nobody. (the fighter reaches for a drink.  The  manager turns on him fiercely)  Drop that, or I'll slug you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fighter, cowed, meekly puts down the  drink.  Nick laughs, hands Peppler a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are -- it's good stuff -- I got it before repeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl in very beautiful evening clothes  with a string of pearls around her neck comes  over to Nick and Peppler.  She holds out the  pearls for Nick's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Nick.  Remember?  These are the ones you got back for me. Peppler looks at them with a professionally avaricious eye. Peppler

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh-ugh!  This is your night off. Suddenly the music of the radio stops as it  is switched to another station.  The voice of  a news broadcaster comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --32 degrees below in Utica.  Here's the latest  news of the Julia Wolf murder. (Nick turns as he tears this.  The CAMERA TRACKS with him as he goes toward the  radio.  The police captain is listening  there...  he is the one who has changed the  station)  The police have found out that the beautiful blonde secretary was once a gangster's girl.  They are now looking for the gangster.  Clyde Wynant, the girl's  employer is still missing.  This case will....   (By this time, Nick reaches the radio.   He abruptly turns the switch, changing  back to a musical program.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you fellows ever forget business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the captain a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you heard the news?  I'm a gentleman now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora has admitted two young newspaper men  who are standing in the doorway.  Nick walks  over to them. 1st Reporter
